item.title: Ticket #2713 (patch wptexturize to leave text inside ...) created
item.dc:creator: n8v
item.description:
My issue was initially similar to ticket #2647 but I fixed it a different way (see patch) because I wasn't sharp enough to spot the missing parenthese.

Also, I noticed that it didn't seem to properly skip texturizing text inside tags nested within code/pre/etc. blocks. So for example, even after applying Justinsomnia's patch from #2647 : 

<pre>
foo --bar
<samp>bar --foo</samp>
baz --foo
</pre>

gets texturized as: 

<pre>
foo --bar
<samp>bar –foo</samp>
baz –foo
</pre>

I tested my patch with the sample above, and confirmed that it resumes texturizing after the closing pre tag.

item.title: Ticket #2712 (Need to filter posts before post_type and user checks) updated
item.dc:creator: skeltoac
item.description: Have you considered using a custom post type?

item.title: Ticket #2712 (Need to filter posts before post_type and user checks) created
item.dc:creator: ev3rywh3re
item.description:
I'm working on making EventCalendar3 work with 2.1Alpha. It actually works well using standard filters while preserving the status = future with one exception.

Once you actually send the sql request with WP_Query, it goes through another check for status = future. This is around line 886 in query.php. I thought this may be a good place to add a filter like "posts_result". A filter can then be run on the results before the posts get the status check then filter "the_posts". I'm just going to paste a sample for query.php: 

$this->request = apply_filters('posts_request', $request);
$this->posts = $wpdb->get_results($this->request);
$this->posts = apply_filters('posts_results', $this->posts);
// Check post status to determine if post should be displayed.

The only alternative is to publish those posts which is probably not really the correct since they should probably still be "future" posts until the proper date.

item.title: Ticket #1526 (have wp-atom.php generate Atom 1.0 (fix attached)) updated
item.dc:creator: enricopulatzo
item.description:
re: NikolasCo You're 100% percent right I should be issuing patches to the previously uploaded file--sorry about that. The reason I didn't was a poor one (namely I created something that worked for me before seeing the work others had put in). My files were created prior to me checking trac and I really shouldn't have added them to the mix (at the very least not on someone else's thread.

The CDATA issue is that when you have elements that have a type="xhtml" you lose the semantic benefits by wrapping the content in a CDATA block. From my understanding of a CDATA block, data encapsulated won't necessarily mean anything to an XML interpreter. If you use type="xhtml" in Atom the content better be well-formatted XHTML.

I'll rework my offering based on what you've already added, with the exception of the CDATA part--that shouldn't be there. If people want to use XML feeds then by golly, they should be offering well-formed XML feeds (the whole "be liberal in what you accept but strict in what you offer" methodology).

item.title: Ticket #2613 (Don't show private posts on front page) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: Patch removes private posts from front page query and adds caps for editing/deleting/reading private posts and pages. Admin is given these caps by default. No other role can read/edit/delete other user's private posts.

item.title: private.diff attached to Ticket #2613
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: No private posts in main query. Add private post/page caps.

item.title: Ticket #2711 (Bookmarklet instructions should be browser specific) created
item.dc:creator: mplace
item.description:
This suggestion comes from one of our [www.xmission.com] users and credit for this discovery should be given to <locutus@â€¦>:

Just a suggestion... maybe customize some of the interface text for different browsers.

For example, the Write Post page contains the following text:

=========== WordPress bookmarklet

Right click on the following link and choose "Add to favorites" to create a posting shortcut. ===========

Since I use Firefox on Linux, what I should choose is not found. Hence, maybe detect the browser, and add the relevant text?

I.e., on Firefox, it's "Bookmark this Link..."

item.title: Ticket #2710 (list_cats / wp_list_cats: hide_empty does not hide cats with non-empty ...) created
item.dc:creator: janX
item.description: I'd like for the hide_empty options in list_cats and wp_list_cats to NOT hide categories which are empty, but that have sub-categories that have posts in them. Looking at the code it is obvious why this happens (template-functions-category.php, line 322). I have a fix for this, though.

item.title: Ticket #2702 (Easier way to change page order (AJAX/jQuery?)) updated
item.dc:creator: FireMotion
item.description:
Another suggestion to make life easier:

In Edit Page maybe there could be the Move Up / Move Down buttons, in addition to the existing input box. Having those buttons is more user-friendly for anyone. Especially for clueless newbies.
